instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00244: What is 820-00244? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1534: What is A1534? A1534 is a model number for a 12 inch size Macbook  from years 2015, 2016 with EMC 2746, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00045, 820-00244..
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power anywhere
threads.message:
2016 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 12” MacBook

Received board only with no history. Looks to be in excellent shape and no signs of any prior work. (<CHIP>U6100</CHIP> has a crack on the edge but I don’t think that would cause this issue).

Not getting any power anywhere. Even if <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> was bad wouldn’t I still see something on F3050? J9600 looks fine. F3050 resistance to ground matches good board. 

Known good DCin cables and charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power anywhere
threads.message:
If <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> is chipped you are screwed. If it really is dead there is no way to get the SSD to work anymore as there is code in <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> that is unique to the SSD on the board. 
Post a picture of <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> to asses damage. If you have an adapter see if you can read <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> through J6100.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power anywhere
threads.message:
No Title

[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 39434"]If <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> is chipped you are screwed. If it really is dead there is no way to get the SSD to work anymore as there is code in <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> that is unique to the SSD on the board.
Post a picture of <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> to asses damage. If you have an adapter see if you can read <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> through J6100.[/QUOTE]

No adapter. Recommendations on these?

Pics attached. I’ve seen these “pre-programmed” on eBay. Figured I’d at least get power on the board somewhere first, then worry about swapping/ programming.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power anywhere
threads.message:
That chip is fucked. There will be no way to get the SSD to work that I currently know off. For now this board is RIP. No use in buying a chip as the SSD won't work anyway, but if you want to try then go ahead.
Board will not power on with the cracked chip at least.
